body: No longer relevant

This issue was resolved with the completion of multi-application support in #454.  With the addition of #454, each application can have its own table so a Fluo instance supports running Fluo on multiple tables using separate applications.  #22 is still outstanding but allows workers to process notifications in multiple tables.
Also document that data does not have to exists for weak notifications.  Need to document somewhere the once only semantics of regular notifications, and the potential for collisions.

A "dumb" solution would be to encourage a shaded jar with relocated classes. Very inelegant when compared to a solution like OSGI or felix and requires more work to build observers to run in Fluo, but it should work w/o any additional dependencies.

>  A "dumb" solution would be to encourage a shaded jar with relocated classes.

Thats a very interesting solution.  I have never used that before.   Thanks for pointing that out, that may be a good way to go.

>  Thanks for pointing that out, that may be a good way to go.

If nothing else, it's not bad to isolate the Fluo dependencies that way. Forcing users to do it themselves is a little heinous, IMO. Hopefully, you can rely on a group of people using a Fluo instance to have some consistency among themselves. You just focus the effort on preventing your own dependencies from causing problems or similar.
I'm not sure how to correctly handle that in imports either. I'm sure google knows if you ask it.

> If nothing else, it's not bad to isolate the Fluo dependencies that way.

I suppose that would require building a fat jar for the Fluo worker with relocated impl classes.  I am going to research this option to understand it better.    

> Forcing users to do it themselves is a little heinous, IMO.

How does that compare to forcing user to use OSGI???  I am not familiar with either, so I am not sure which is more burdensome.  One possibility I was thinking about is that fluo takes care of it with isolation based on a certain directory structure (ie. app/observer1/lib/... and app/observer2/lib/..).  However I am not in favor of this option and would rather leverage standards if possible after my experiences with accumulo start.

> How does that compare to forcing user to use OSGI??? I am not familiar with either, so I am not sure which is more burdensome

I'm not sure either. I just know that people often scoff at learning how to do something in Maven beyond "build a jar" or "build an assembly" :)
Created #543 as follow on issue

While working on a generic export recipe for Fluo, I thought of following use case that would be nice to support :
- Fluo instance is using an Accumulo 1.8.0 instance.
- A Fluo observer is exporting to a table in a Accumulo 1.6.4 instance.

In this case the Fluo framework needs the Accumulo 1.8.0 client libs and deps, however the observer needs the Accumulo 1.6.4 client libs and deps.
Where are you thinking of putting this?  In its own github repo?  I suppose it will need to be released inorder to use it?
Yes.  I think it should be in its own github repo like https://github.com/revelc/revelc
+1.  Made a few minor comments but otherwise looks good to me.
Not sure if this change will have any impact on intellij

I was reviewing the work done in #8 and determined its not robust enough to drop the truncation markers placed by fluo-gc.  In #8 we introduced transactors which advertise their oldest active snapshot on ZK.   Fluo-gc uses this info ZK to determine whats safe to collect.  The advertisements are done using Curator PersistentEphemeralNodes.  These nodes may vanish for short periods of time, which means there is a small chance that GC may collect something that is should not.   Thats ok now with the truncation markers, because those prevent scans reading past a point of garbage collection.  However this would not be ok if truncation markers were dropped and a scan read past a GC point and conclude nothing is there.

To solve this problem, I am thinking of dropping truncation markers and making the Oracle an authority on GC times.  In what I am thinking, the Oracle would do the following :
-  Periodically Read the oldest active snapshot time from ZK, hold it in memory, and write out a GC time ZK.
- When clients request timestamps, also return the GC time (its held in memory from the last update).

Clients would use the GC time returned by the oracle when committing or closing a snapshot.  That might look like the following.
- client gets start timestamp timeA for tx1 from oracle
- client gets commit timestamp timeB and gc time timeG from oracle for tx1
- client checkts that timeA > timeG, if not it throws an exception and rolls back phase 1 of commit

The Fluo GC iterator would be changed to read the GC time written to ZK by the Oracle.
I suppose this problem could happen if the process dies at that point for some reason.  What happens when it gets in this state?  Should we open a follow on issue to do this in a better way?
I am not sure if this is a timing issue or a larger problem.  Now that we no longer time out, we will know if there is a larger problem and can add an a new issue then.

```
$ grep -r metrics.yaml .
./pom.xml:              <exclude>**/metrics.yaml</exclude>
./modules/distribution/src/main/scripts/fluo:  copy_config metrics.yaml
./modules/distribution/src/main/scripts/mini-fluo:  copy_config metrics.yaml
```

> There are still some references to metrics.yaml that need to be removed:

Need to update metrics.md.  In that docs is mentions that JMX will be setup if no reporter is configured.  Could remove that.
Updated JMX mention in metrics.md in e8381206

Currently working on a solution that allows a transaction to push a pair of writes into the background.   The first of writes is completed in the background before the second is started.  This frees up the thread to start working on another transaction, getting more data ready to batch write.  I am running this fix now on a cluster and the results are good.

With the changes in #590 and #592, the page observer was able to keep up with the page loader.  I ran two loads.   First ran 36 files and second loaded 72 files, both using 36 load task.    

![keepnup-tps](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1268739/11911649/9ae4299e-a5ea-11e5-9009-d071be20677f.png)
![keepnup-q](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1268739/11911648/9ad71c4a-a5ea-11e5-90e7-294c582a06c7.png)

For the 2nd load, the workers had sat idle a little bit and were not looking for notifications as aggressively.  So it took a bit for the workers to react to the page loader.

Below are the read write rates for all of the observers on this experiment.

![keepnup-rw-rates](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1268739/11911729/52e45102-a5ed-11e5-9392-50dddd9e8e0b.png)

I have been running test all day on this EC2 cluster and making changes to Fluo in the process. These changes were experiments leading to #590 and #592.  Below shows the TX/sec rate over the day.   Notice the loader rates were really high and then go down over time.  My theory is that as I sped up the Fluo workers, they used more resources taking them away from the loader task and slowing down loading.   

![all-day-tps](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1268739/11911742/0adb64da-a5ee-11e5-9bf0-da931ba586ff.png)
![all-day-q](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1268739/11911743/0afdec9e-a5ee-11e5-8ead-2eed0cf69448.png)

I kept using the same Accumulo tables for all of the test.  So by the end of the day, quite a bit of data had built up in them.  The table `webindex_search` is the index being built by the Fluo webindex application.  The table `webindex` is used by Fluo.    

![accumulo-monitor](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1268739/11911745/29e586a8-a5ee-11e5-8148-ab0cb284a2e0.png)

This approach for committing transactions would be similar to async io methods.  No threads would wait on a transaction when the conditional writer is working on it.   Conceptually a transaction would be submitted to the conditional writer, then when that completes a thread would pick the transaction up and start working on its next step.
Closing this since we moved to InfluxDB and Grafana  starting with #569

I was able to launch a cluster using ami-61bbf104, however when I search for that AMI in the EC2 console I can not find it.  That made me scratch my head.   Starting at the following page and poking around, I was able to determine the problem.

https://aws.amazon.com/marketplace/pp/B00O7WM7QW

The image ami-61bbf104 is deprecated and no longer available for new customers.  So I guess since I used it before, its still available to me.   The latest centos 7 image is ami-6d1c2007, we need to update to that in the scripts.  

I wonder if there is a programatic way to get the latest centos7 ami using the AWS marketpalce ID for centos 7.

I added String getters for data classes.  Following naming convention of snapshot.
String getters look good to me.
I discovered the wait command implementation is setting the client retry timeout to 500ms

Seems I ran into this problem before #456 and fixed it incorrectly.  The reason I did not properly fix it then is I was making the following incorrect assumption :
- If a notification causes an observer to create other notifications, then in the case of failures rerunning the observer with the same notification will always recreate the same notifications.

However this is not true if the observer runs again and finds there is nothing to do. Mainly in the case where it failed previously, but did complete part of the 2nd phase of commit.   In this case it may not recreate the notifications it created last time and those notifications will never be created until something tries to read the locked data (which may never happen).

Since the solution in #456 was based on an incorrect premise I may be able to delete the notifications earlier as was done before the "fix" for #456 in addition to setting notifications in the lock phase.

Thinking about this, if setting notifications during 1st phase of commit then would use start timestamp.  Need to be careful that notifications are not deleted when they should not be.  Notifications are currently deleted using the start timestamp of a transactions.   When writing notification using startTs (instead of commitTs as is currently done) need to do something to avoid a situation like the following where notification created by TX3 is lost.

```
TX1 snotify C1 with startTs 10 commitTs 12
TX3 starts with startTs 13
TX2 triggered by C1 with startTs 14
TX2 ACK C1 with startTs 14 (deletes notifcation using startTs 14)
TX3 snotify C1 with startTs 13 commitTs 17
```

Another issue is that even if the notification was not deleted in the situation above, the current code would consider it already acknowledged because this based on ACK timestamp vs Notification timestamp.  So TX2 would write an ACK with timestamp 14 which would supersede the notification from TX3.

Was thinking of writing notifications while writing locks, however there is a problem with this.  If a transaction writes a notification w/o writing all of its lock, then an observer triggered by the transaction is not guaranteed to see everything the transaction wrote.  Can only write a notification after all locks are written.   Beginning to think that strong notifications should be written in the same way that weak notifications are currently written.   Weak notifications are written after all locks are written, but before finishing the commit on the primary column.  In the case of failures the transactions will be rolled back and all notifications rewitten.  For strong notifications, need to ensure observers fail when triggered by a notification written for a transaction that fails.
With these change, I was able to successfully run stress test locally while continually stopping and starting fluo with a script.

I implemented async commit.  With async commit changes I am seeing much improved processing rates and much higher resource utilization on the cluster.  I ran webindex on a 20 node EC2 cluster and saw the following.  Previously with a similar setup I saw a peak of processing around 1000 web pages per second.  In the test below I loaded 80 common crawl files in two batches of 40.

![tx_per_sec](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1268739/14757527/c6bd1586-08c2-11e6-9347-8a1b2eab189d.png)

I set the cluster to have 100M of commit memory.   Below is a new plot for this change that shows how many transactions are working their way through the commit process.

![committing](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1268739/14757529/cd5f9d32-08c2-11e6-9d15-3a12826958f7.png)

Of course seeing much higher rates for setting.  Estimate below is indexing 50,000 links per second peak from web pages.

![set](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1268739/14757532/d3da49f0-08c2-11e6-87c3-fd8348b45427.png)

While the new async commit changes significantly increase throughput, they make transaction commits take longer.  This impacts follow on observers by increasing their lock wait time.   Need to look into ways to minimize the impact of this.

![lock_wait](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1268739/14757533/d6858cbe-08c2-11e6-8c6c-bfc9a3d99b47.png)

>  If the Accumulo itself supported async callbacks it could make the callbacks immediately when something finished processing.

Doesn't Thrift generate async service interfaces (and we just ignore it now)?

> Doesn't Thrift generate async service interfaces (and we just ignore it now)?

Oh yeah I remember seeing that.   I had not even thought that far ahead.   I was just thinking of adding something to the existing client side code that informs you sooner when something is done.  Once the callback mechanism is in the API it can gradually be pushed further and further in the implementation.

Used the advice in this [email from twill dev list](http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/twill-dev/201604.mbox/%3CCAHqY-MO5ev-O9KEW6t8hAKrXZ0T0Jn6HtJLdfHWuA628-UhT2w%40mail.gmail.com%3E) and it worked really well.  Set twill to reserve 1G and gave workers 5G while running webindex and workers ran for long periods of time w/o being killed.
I added support for configuring the reserved memory in fluo-io/zetten#139 and its working well.

The option to run with `-h` no longer works so it should be remove when users run `fluo help`

```
classpath     Prints the classpath needed for fluo clients.  Run with -h to learn more.
```

This should be changed in `modules/distribution/src/main/scripts/fluo`
This was addressed with [1.0.0-beta-2 release](https://fluo.apache.org/release-notes/1.0.0-beta-2/).

Its not easy to write a test for this, so I would not attempt it. It would be nice to manually test this change.   You can manually test by doing the following :

Edit modules/integration/src/test/resources/log4j.properties and change `log4j.logger.org.apache.fluo=ERROR` to `log4j.logger.org.apache.fluo=INFO`.  Don't check this change in, just changing temporarily to see logging output when running command below.

The following command will run the OracleIT.  Look for your new logging output when the OracleIT integration test runs. I think you will need to change the delay to zero.

``` bash
 mvn -Dit.test=OracleIT -Dtest=foo -Dfindbugs.skip -Dcheckstyle.skip -DfailIfNoTests=false verify
```
It would be nice if your commit message started with `fixes #662`.  Github automatically recognizes this format in commit messages.

Essentially, we need to switch from the fluo parent POM to the ASF parent POM, which serve similar purposes. There may be things in the fluo parent POM which are not in the ASF parent POM. In those cases, we need to reconcile the differences, either by dropping them, pushing them down into the individual project POMs, or by turning the current fluo parent POM into an intermediate POM, whose parent is the ASF parent POM (which I think is probably the best route).
I like the path of making the [current parent pom](https://github.com/fluo-io/resources/blob/613cf66b7894e9f376b6263a4a6ced8326e3e8dc/pom.xml) have Apache as a parent and reconciling the differences.

@Garvit244 responding to your email for more info here on the issue.  I am not sure exactly what needs to be done, but I will try to explain what I think needs to be done.  I may be wrong about some things.

Some quick background.  The [Fluo project pom](https://github.com/fluo-io/resources/blob/613cf66b7894e9f376b6263a4a6ced8326e3e8dc/pom.xml) provides common functionality across Fluo project poms ([Fluo pom](https://github.com/apache/incubator-fluo/blob/fee0ca74d04aad8d0dc599817ac5deca19f92c44/pom.xml) and [Recipes pom](https://github.com/apache/incubator-fluo-recipes/blob/93f482aa447e5f63c3e3406f05e328404ac143ba/pom.xml)).  For example the Fluo parent pom sets up code formatting, findbugs, etc.  Therefore each project pom does not have to duplicate all of this.  The projects poms [used to duplicate](https://github.com/apache/incubator-fluo/commit/2911b373357ee87c99e019475f3ade13c499205b#diff-600376dffeb79835ede4a0b285078036) all of this before creating the Fluo project pom.

Now that we are moving to Apache we want to use config from the [Apache pom](https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/apache/apache/18/apache-18.pom) to do releases.   We also want to keep things from the  [Fluo Project pom](https://github.com/fluo-io/resources/blob/613cf66b7894e9f376b6263a4a6ced8326e3e8dc/pom.xml) like code formatting.  To accomplish this we can add the Apache as a parent of the Fluo project pom.

Also we need to remove the current info about releasing to Sonatype (where io.flou releases were done) from any of the poms where it may occur.

The following is the high level overview of what I think needs to be done.
1. Add [Apache pom](https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/apache/apache/18/apache-18.pom) as parent of [Fluo project pom](https://github.com/fluo-io/resources/blob/613cf66b7894e9f376b6263a4a6ced8326e3e8dc/pom.xml)
2. Reconcile plugin config that occur in both poms.  Feel free to ask about reconciling any duplicate plugins with different config.
3. Remove Sonatype distribution management section from Fluo project pom.  Look for other Sonatye stuff to remove. (should inherit distribution management from Apache parent pom)
4. Release new version of Fluo project pom
5. Update [Fluo pom](https://github.com/apache/incubator-fluo/blob/fee0ca74d04aad8d0dc599817ac5deca19f92c44/pom.xml) and [Recipes pom](https://github.com/apache/incubator-fluo-recipes/blob/93f482aa447e5f63c3e3406f05e328404ac143ba/pom.xml) to use new version of Fluo project pom.

We were planning on releasing the Fluo project pom to Sonatype because we have not transitioned that project to Apache yet.   @ctubbsii  how can the Fluo project pom release to Sonatype if it drops Sonatype distribution management and inherits Apache distribution management?

An alternative to modifiying the existing  [Fluo project pom][1] is to create a new parent for Fluo and Fluo Recipes.  This could be stored in a branch of Fluo.   Then we would have a graph like the following.  This idea was suggested by @ctubbsii yesterday offline and I just remembered it.
- FluoProjectParent has a parent of Apache pom
- Fluo has a parent of FluoProjectParent
- Fluo Recipes has a parent of FluoProjectParent

FluoProjectParent would be brand new and would have code formatting, findbugs, etc.   FluoProjectParent would be stored in a branch of the Fluo project that only has the pom.

@keith-turner Second approach looks good to me by that I didn't need to do any changes in current Fluo project pom. When new FluoProjectParent is done we only need to change Fluo project pom until then we can use current [Fluo project pom](https://github.com/fluo-io/resources/blob/613cf66b7894e9f376b6263a4a6ced8326e3e8dc/pom.xml)
